You are a clinical documentation specialist. Your task is to generate a concise "Brief Hospital Course" summary from the provided clinical notes. This summary should:
1. Capture the essential clinical trajectory of the patient's hospital stay
2. Include key diagnoses, procedures, and treatments
3. Highlight significant clinical events and their resolutions
4. Be suitable for clinical coding purposes
5. Use appropriate medical terminology
6. Be organized chronologically when relevant

Output only the Brief Hospital Course summary without any additional commentary.

Generate a Brief Hospital Course summary for the following clinical notes:

=== NURSING NOTES ===
Day 1: 68-year-old male admitted from ED with acute onset chest pain radiating to left arm.
Vital signs: BP 165/95, HR 98, RR 20, SpO2 96% on room air, Temp 37.1C.
Patient appears diaphoretic and anxious.
IV access established, 12-lead ECG completed.
Nitroglycerin administered per protocol.
Cardiac enzymes drawn - Troponin I: 2.1 ng/mL (elevated).
Patient placed on continuous cardiac monitoring.

Day 2: Patient underwent emergent cardiac catheterization at 0600.
Found 95% occlusion of LAD, 70% occlusion of RCA.
Successful PCI with drug-eluting stent to LAD.
Post-procedure: stable hemodynamics, groin site without hematoma.
Started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 81mg, clopidogrel 75mg).
Initiated high-intensity statin therapy.
Pain well controlled with PRN analgesics.

Day 3: Patient progressing well.
Ambulating with physical therapy.
No further chest pain episodes.
Echocardiogram performed - LVEF 45-50%, mild hypokinesis of anterior wall.
Cardiac rehab consulted.
Diet advanced to cardiac diet, tolerating well.

=== PHYSICIAN NOTES ===
Admission H&P:
68M with PMH of HTN, hyperlipidemia, former smoker (quit 5 years ago), presenting with NSTEMI.
ECG: ST depressions in V3-V6, T wave inversions in leads II, III, aVF.
Plan: Urgent cardiac catheterization, anticoagulation, cardiac enzymes trending.

Progress Note Day 2:
Successful PCI to LAD with DES placement. RCA lesion medically managed for now.
Start DAPT, high-intensity statin, beta blocker, ACE inhibitor.
Goal LDL < 70.
Cardiac echo pending.

Progress Note Day 3:
Recovering well post-PCI. Echo shows mild LV dysfunction likely due to anterior MI.
Medically optimized. Ready for discharge planning.
Will need outpatient cardiac rehab.
Follow-up with cardiology in 2 weeks.

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and former tobacco use who presented with acute onset chest pain and was found to have NSTEMI. Initial workup revealed elevated troponin I at 2.1 ng/mL and ECG changes consistent with ischemia. He underwent emergent cardiac catheterization which demonstrated 95% occlusion of the LAD and 70% occlusion of the RCA. Successful percutaneous coronary intervention was performed with drug-eluting stent placement to the LAD. Post-procedure course was uncomplicated. Echocardiogram revealed LVEF of 45-50% with mild anterior wall hypokinesis. He was initiated on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, high-intensity statin, beta blocker, and ACE inhibitor. The patient progressed well, remained chest pain-free, and was ambulating with physical therapy by day 3. Cardiac rehabilitation was consulted. He is being discharged with plans for outpatient cardiac rehabilitation and cardiology follow-up in 2 weeks.

Generate a Brief Hospital Course summary for the following clinical notes:

=== NURSING NOTES ===
Day 1: 72-year-old female admitted with 3-day history of productive cough, fever, and worsening dyspnea.
Vital signs: BP 110/70, HR 105, RR 26, SpO2 88% on room air, Temp 38.9C.
Started on supplemental O2 via nasal cannula at 4L/min - SpO2 improved to 94%.
IV access established, blood cultures drawn x2.
Chest X-ray shows right lower lobe consolidation.
Patient appears fatigued but alert and oriented.

Day 2: Continues to require 4L O2.
IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone and azithromycin) initiated.
Sputum culture obtained - pending.
Patient reporting improved cough, less productive.
Intake adequate, encouraged fluids.

Day 3: Clinical improvement noted.
O2 weaned to 2L NC.
Temperature normalizing - 37.5C.
Respiratory rate improved to 20.
Ambulating to bathroom with minimal assistance.
Sputum culture: Streptococcus pneumoniae, sensitive to current antibiotics.

Day 4: O2 discontinued - maintaining SpO2 95-97% on room air.
Afebrile for 24 hours.
Patient ambulating independently.
Appetite improved.
Plan for discharge with oral antibiotics.

=== PHYSICIAN NOTES ===
Admission Assessment:
72F with COPD (former smoker), HTN presenting with CAP.
CXR: RLL consolidation with air bronchograms.
CURB-65 score: 2 (age >65, RR >30). Moderate severity.
Plan: IV antibiotics, supportive care, monitor for deterioration.

Progress Note Day 3:
Improving clinically on current regimen.
Sputum culture confirms S. pneumoniae - susceptible to beta-lactams.
Will continue current course.
Consider transition to oral therapy if continues to improve.

Discharge Summary:
Diagnosis: Community-acquired pneumonia, right lower lobe.
Patient responded well to IV ceftriaxone/azithromycin.
Transitioning to oral levofloxacin 750mg daily to complete 5-day course.
Follow-up CXR in 4-6 weeks to ensure resolution.

This is a 72-year-old female with a history of COPD and hypertension who was admitted with community-acquired pneumonia presenting as productive cough, fever, and hypoxic respiratory failure requiring supplemental oxygen. Chest X-ray demonstrated right lower lobe consolidation. She was started on intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin for moderate-severity CAP per CURB-65 scoring. Sputum culture grew Streptococcus pneumoniae susceptible to the administered antibiotic regimen. The patient showed gradual clinical improvement with resolution of fever by hospital day 3 and successful weaning from supplemental oxygen to room air by day 4. She was transitioned to oral levofloxacin to complete a 5-day course of antibiotics. At discharge, she was afebrile, maintaining adequate oxygen saturation on room air, and ambulating independently. Follow-up chest X-ray is recommended in 4-6 weeks to confirm radiographic resolution.

Generate a Brief Hospital Course summary for the following clinical notes:

=== NURSING NOTES ===
Day 1: 45-year-old male with Type 1 diabetes admitted from ED with DKA.
Vital signs: BP 100/60, HR 115, RR 28 (Kussmaul), SpO2 98%, Temp 37.0C.
Patient appears lethargic, reports 2 days of nausea/vomiting, decreased oral intake.
Labs: Glucose 485 mg/dL, pH 7.12, bicarbonate 8, anion gap 28, positive serum ketones.
Transferred to ICU for insulin drip and monitoring.
IV normal saline bolus initiated, then switched to 0.45% NS.
Potassium replacement started.
Strict I/O, hourly glucose monitoring.

ICU Day 1 (Night): Glucose trending down (350 at midnight).
Anion gap closing (now 18).
Mental status improving.
Continued insulin drip, electrolyte repletion.

Day 2: Anion gap closed (10), pH normalized (7.38).
Patient alert and oriented, tolerating clear liquids.
Transitioned from insulin drip to subcutaneous insulin.
Endocrine consulted for insulin regimen optimization.
Identified trigger: patient ran out of insulin supplies and missed doses.

Day 3: Tolerating regular diet.
Glucose control stable on adjusted insulin regimen.
Diabetes education provided.
Social work consulted for medication access issues.
Discharge planning initiated.

=== PHYSICIAN NOTES ===
ICU Admission:
45M T1DM presenting with DKA. Precipitant: medication non-adherence (insulin)
Severe DKA: pH 7.12, AG 28, glucose 485.
Plan: Aggressive fluid resuscitation, insulin drip per DKA protocol, electrolyte monitoring q2h.
Watch for cerebral edema, hypokalemia.

Progress Note Day 2:
DKA resolved - anion gap closed, ketones cleared.
Transitioning to subcutaneous insulin.
Endocrine recommendations: Lantus 24 units nightly, Humalog sliding scale with meals.
Patient education on DKA prevention, sick day rules.

Discharge Note:
DKA secondary to insulin non-adherence resolved.
Patient stable on new insulin regimen.
Social work arranged medication assistance program.
Close endocrine follow-up arranged.

The patient is a 45-year-old male with Type 1 diabetes mellitus who was admitted to the ICU with severe diabetic ketoacidosis precipitated by medication non-adherence after running out of insulin supplies. On presentation, he had a blood glucose of 485 mg/dL, pH of 7.12, bicarbonate of 8, and anion gap of 28 with positive serum ketones. He was treated per DKA protocol with aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation, continuous insulin infusion, and potassium replacement with close monitoring. The anion gap closed within 24 hours and pH normalized by hospital day 2. He was successfully transitioned from insulin drip to subcutaneous insulin with an optimized regimen per endocrinology recommendations consisting of Lantus 24 units nightly and Humalog sliding scale with meals. Comprehensive diabetes education was provided including sick day rules and DKA prevention. Social work was consulted and arranged enrollment in a medication assistance program to address insulin access barriers. The patient was discharged in stable condition with close endocrinology follow-up arranged.

Generate a Brief Hospital Course summary for the following clinical notes:

=== NURSING NOTES ===
Day 1: 58-year-old female admitted for elective total right knee arthroplasty.
Pre-op vitals stable. NPO confirmed.
Transported to OR at 0700.
Returned from PACU at 1400, alert and oriented.
Pain managed with PCA morphine.
Hemovac drain in place, minimal output.
Neurovascular checks q1h - intact.
Anticoagulation initiated per protocol (enoxaparin 40mg subQ).

Post-op Day 1:
Physical therapy evaluation - patient able to stand with walker.
Pain controlled with transition to oral opioids.
Drain removed - total output 150mL.
Ambulated 50 feet with PT assist.
Continued DVT prophylaxis.

Post-op Day 2:
Continued PT - ambulating 100 feet with walker.
Transitioned to oral pain medications PRN.
Knee ROM: 0-80 degrees.
Wound clean and dry, no signs of infection.
Ready for discharge to acute rehab.

=== PHYSICIAN NOTES ===
Operative Note:
Procedure: Right total knee arthroplasty
Indicat: Severe osteoarthritis, failed conservative management
Implant: Zimmer NexGen posterior-stabilized prosthesis
EBL: 200mL
No complications.

Post-op Day 1:
Recovering well. Good pain control.
XR: Components well-positioned, no evidence of fracture.
Weight bearing as tolerated with walker.
Continue DVT prophylaxis.

Discharge Summary:
58F s/p R TKA for OA. Uncomplicated post-op course.
Discharging to acute rehabilitation facility.
DVT prophylaxis: enoxaparin x 2 weeks.
Follow-up: 2 weeks for staple removal, 6 weeks for post-op visit.

This is a 58-year-old female who was admitted for elective right total knee arthroplasty due to severe osteoarthritis that had failed conservative management. She underwent uncomplicated right TKA with placement of a Zimmer NexGen posterior-stabilized prosthesis. Estimated blood loss was 200mL. Post-operative recovery was uneventful. Pain was initially managed with PCA morphine and subsequently transitioned to oral analgesics. Immediate post-operative X-ray confirmed appropriate component positioning without fracture. DVT prophylaxis was maintained with enoxaparin 40mg subcutaneous daily. Physical therapy was initiated on post-operative day 1, and the patient progressed well, ambulating 100 feet with a walker and achieving knee range of motion of 0-80 degrees by post-operative day 2. The surgical wound remained clean and dry without signs of infection. The hemovac drain was removed on post-operative day 1 with minimal drainage. The patient met discharge criteria and was transferred to an acute rehabilitation facility. She is to continue enoxaparin for 2 weeks for DVT prophylaxis and follow up in 2 weeks for staple removal and at 6 weeks for post-operative evaluation.

Generate a Brief Hospital Course summary for the following clinical notes:

=== NURSING NOTES ===
Day 1: 82-year-old female admitted from nursing facility with altered mental status and fever.
Vital signs: BP 90/55, HR 110, RR 22, SpO2 92% on RA, Temp 39.2C.
Patient confused, baseline dementia per family.
Foley catheter in place, urine appears cloudy.
IV fluids initiated per sepsis protocol.
Blood and urine cultures obtained.
Lactate 3.2 mmol/L.
Broad-spectrum antibiotics started (vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam).

Day 2: Hemodynamically stable after fluid resuscitation.
BP improved to 105/65.
Mental status slightly improved.
Urine culture: >100,000 CFU/mL E. coli, sensitive to ciprofloxacin.
Blood cultures: no growth to date.
Antibiotics narrowed to ciprofloxacin IV.
Foley catheter changed.

Day 3: Afebrile.
Mental status returning to baseline per family.
Tolerating diet.
Converted to oral ciprofloxacin.
Blood cultures: no growth at 48 hours.

Day 4: Stable. Alert and oriented to person, consistent with baseline.
Ambulating with assistance.
Discharge to nursing facility planned.

=== PHYSICIAN NOTES ===
Admission:
82F with dementia, recurrent UTI, presenting with urosepsis.
SIRS criteria met. Sepsis-3 criteria positive (qSOFA 2).
Plan: Aggressive resuscitation, empiric antibiotics, source control.

Progress Note Day 2:
Improving with treatment. Urine culture confirms E. coli UTI.
De-escalate to targeted therapy.
Discuss catheter management with facility - intermittent cath preferred.

Discharge Summary:
Diagnosis: Urosepsis secondary to complicated UTI (E. coli)
Completed 3 days IV antibiotics, transitioning to 7-day oral ciprofloxacin.
Recommend: intermittent catheterization, avoid chronic indwelling catheter.
Return precautions given to facility staff.

This is an 82-year-old female nursing facility resident with baseline dementia and recurrent urinary tract infections who was admitted with urosepsis. On presentation, she met sepsis criteria with fever to 39.2C, hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate of 3.2 mmol/L. She was started on the sepsis protocol with aggressive fluid resuscitation and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam). Blood and urine cultures were obtained; urine culture subsequently grew greater than 100,000 CFU/mL of E. coli sensitive to fluoroquinolones. Blood cultures remained negative at 48 hours. Antibiotics were de-escalated to targeted therapy with intravenous ciprofloxacin. The patient responded well to treatment with resolution of fever, hemodynamic stabilization, and return of mental status to her baseline by hospital day 3. She was transitioned to oral ciprofloxacin to complete a 7-day course. The indwelling Foley catheter was changed during admission, and recommendations were made to the nursing facility for intermittent catheterization to reduce recurrent UTI risk. She was discharged back to the nursing facility in stable condition with appropriate return precautions.
